title: Biota - Pipers Creek Natural Drainage System monitoring for Seattle Public Utilities
name: biota-pipers-creek-natural-drainage-system-monitoring-for-seattle-public-utilities
notes: Relatively little scientific research or monitoring has occurred in the PacificnNorthwest or elsewhere on the biological effectiveness of restoration efforts in heavilynurbanized watersheds. With the overarching goal of improving ecological health of itsnurban creeks, the City of Seattle is testing innovative approaches to stormwaternmanagement. We report here on four years of pre-project monitoring data collected overn2006-2009 for one such technique: Natural Drainage Systems (NDS). nnThis low-impact development approach is designed to modify the quantity,nquality, and timing of stormwater delivery to creeks and other water bodies. SeattlenPublic Utilities has proposed a large-scale NDS within the Pipers Creek basin of NorthnSeattle that will treat approximately 60% of the Venema Creek sub-basin. The focus ofnNOAAs research effort has been to develop appropriate monitoring parameters andncollect baseline data to evaluate the effectiveness of this major restoration action. Ournselection of study parameters was guided by specific project goals and includes measuresnof physical habitat, contaminant loading, and in-stream biota.nnWe found that the biological health of Pipers Creek is poor compared to forestednstreams in the Puget Sound region, but comparable to other urban streams in the City ofnSeattle. The fish community is dominated by cutthroat trout Oncorhynchus clarki; scoresnfor the benthic index of biological integrity (B-IBI) range from very poor to poor; andndiatom assemblages are composed of a relatively high proportion of species tolerant ofnhigh nutrient levels, organic enrichment, and sedimentation.nnDespite poor stream health, densities of cutthroat trout in three of our five studynreaches were higher than many urban streams and approaching densities of cutthroatnfound in natural streams. This may be due to the migratory nature of cutthroat trout, asnabout half these fish were detected migrating from our study area to lower Piper Creek ornPuget Sound.nnResults from heavy metal sampling were inconsistent. Zinc concentrations innsoil, black fly larvae, and mayfly nymphs collected from Pipers Creek study reaches werensignificantly higher than for forested streams. We did not detect any differences inncopper concentrations between urban and non-urban streams.nnWe hypothesize that in-stream biological health will improve relative to currentnbaseline conditions following Venema NDS implementation, with treated reachesnbeginning to more closely resemble forested conditions. Based on statistical power nanalyses, we recommend that post-project monitoring focus on rate and taxonomicncomposition metrics rather than simple density measurements. Given the City ofnSeattles considerable investment of restoration funds towards NDSs, it is critical thatnpost-project data be collected so as to explicitly test these hypotheses.nnFish (density, biomass, movement, growth, diet), benthic invertebrates, periphyton.
